text:
MONI BASU: Life, for a disabled
child, is not easy anywhere.

But in the middle of a
war zone, it was going
to be particularly difficult.

In 2005, I was embedded
with a US Army unit.

One night, this particular
unit raided a house.

An Iraqi woman
brought out a baby.

The baby's name
was Noor, and she

had been born with a severe
form of spina bifida.
[music playing]
[non-english speech]

MONI BASU: But then
she went back to Iraq.

And, really, the trouble for
Noor and her family began then.

She should have been seeing
a neurosurgeon every year.

But in Iraq, a lot
of the doctors,

especially specialists,
had fled the country.
[non-english speech]
[horn honks]

- Every time I see Noor, quite
a few years have gone by.

And I'm always amazed by
how that little baby--

who everyone said
would not make it--

has blossomed into a
beautiful young girl.

She had to have her head
shaved before the surgery.

And she thought she
was going to a salon.

But instead we took
her to a barber shop.
[interposing voices]
[non-english speech]
[squeal]
[beeping]

- There was a swelling
along the shunt.
And it would discharge again.
So we removed Noor's shunt.
[non-english speech]
[non-english speech]

PETER SSENYONGA: I do
not think Noor will walk.

That does not mean Noor
cannot actually live her
life to the fullest potential.

MONI BASU: Noor holds onto this
hope that she is going to walk.

And I think her family has
allowed her to hope and dream,

because it's what
keeps her going.
[non-english speech]

MONI BASU: The only reason
he does anything in life

is to make sure that
his only daughter
has a chance at happiness.
